questions.question: A botanist investigates how the intensity of light affects the rate of photosynthesis in a fern. In this experiment, what is the 'intensity of light' called?
questions.explanation: The independent variable is the factor that is deliberately changed or manipulated by the experimenter to observe its effect on the dependent variable (rate of photosynthesis).

questions.question: An engineer writes: 'If the diameter of the turbine blades is increased, then the electrical output will increase.' Name this step of the scientific method.
questions.explanation: A hypothesis is a testable prediction stated in an 'If...then...' format about the relationship between variables.

questions.question: The mass of a specific protein molecule is $0.000000000000000000000482\text{ kg}$. Express this mass in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 22 places to the right: $0.000000000000000000000482 = 4.82 \times 10^{-22}\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A massive data center processes $51,800,000,000,000,000$ bits of data per day. Express this number in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 16 places to the left: $51,800,000,000,000,000 = 5.18 \times 10^{16}$.

questions.question: How many significant figures are in the measurement $0.00007030\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: Leading zeros are not significant. The digits $7$, $0$, $3$, and the trailing $0$ are significant, giving a total of 4 significant figures.

questions.question: Identify which of these is a fundamental (base) quantity in physics.
questions.explanation: Luminous intensity is one of the seven SI base quantities. Voltage and density are derived quantities.

questions.question: Identify which of these is a derived quantity.
questions.explanation: Force is derived from mass and acceleration ($F = ma$). Time and length are fundamental quantities.

questions.question: Which of these is a fundamental SI unit?
questions.explanation: The mole (mol) is the SI base unit for amount of substance. Weber and Henry are derived units.

questions.question: Which of these is a derived SI unit?
questions.explanation: The Watt (W) is a derived unit for power ($1\text{ W} = 1\text{ J/s}$). Candela and Kelvin are fundamental SI units.

questions.question: A high-speed torpedo moves at a speed of $198\text{ km/h}$. Convert this speed to meters per second ($\text{m/s}$).
questions.explanation: To convert from km/h to m/s, divide by $3.6$: $198 \div 3.6 = 55\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A robotic arm moves at a speed of $12.5\text{ m/s}$. What is this speed in kilometers per hour ($\text{km/h}$)?
questions.explanation: To convert from m/s to km/h, multiply by $3.6$: $12.5 \times 3.6 = 45\text{ km/h}$.

questions.question: A specialized contact lens is $0.000145\text{ m}$ thick. How many millimeters (mm) is this thickness?
A coil of fiber-optic line is $44{,}800\text{ mm}$ long. Express this length in meters.
A flat-screen television has a width of $124.5\text{ cm}$. What is this width in meters?
A solar panel has a surface area of $18{,}500\text{ cm}^2$. Convert this area to square meters ($\text{m}^2$).
A cyclist travels $1{,}600\text{ m}$ due North, then immediately turns around and travels $400\text{ m}$ due South. The entire trip takes $240\text{ s}$. Calculate the cyclist's average velocity.
questions.explanation: Displacement is $1{,}600\text{ m}$ North minus $400\text{ m}$ South, which equals $1{,}200\text{ m}$ North. Average velocity $= \text{displacement} / \text{time} = 1{,}200\text{ m} / 240\text{ s} = 5\text{ m/s}$ North.

questions.question: A motorboat increases its speed uniformly from $6\text{ m/s}$ to $42\text{ m/s}$ in $9\text{ s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the boat's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Acceleration is calculated using $a = \frac{v_f - v_i}{t} = \frac{42 - 6}{9} = \frac{36}{9} = 4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A subway train slows down uniformly for a stop, going from $28\text{ m/s}$ to $4\text{ m/s}$ in $6\text{ s}$. Calculate the acceleration of the train, including the correct sign to indicate direction.
questions.explanation: $a = \frac{4 - 28}{6} = \frac{-24}{6} = -4\text{ m/s}^2$. The negative sign indicates that the acceleration is in the direction opposite to the velocity (deceleration).

questions.question: A person walks $80\text{ m}$ due East and then $80\text{ m}$ due West back to the starting point. The entire trip takes $40\text{ s}$. Calculate the person's average speed and the magnitude of their average velocity.
questions.explanation: Average speed is total distance over time: $\frac{160\text{ m}}{40\text{ s}} = 4\text{ m/s}$. Average velocity is displacement over time: displacement $= 0$ (returns to start), so velocity $= 0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A car travels $21\text{ km}$ due North and then $28\text{ km}$ due East. Calculate the total distance traveled and the magnitude of the car's displacement from the starting point.
questions.explanation: Total distance is the sum of the path lengths: $21 + 28 = 49\text{ km}$. Displacement is the straight-line distance from start to finish, found using the Pythagorean theorem: $\sqrt{21^2 + 28^2} = \sqrt{441 + 784} = \sqrt{1{,}225} = 35\text{ km}$.

questions.question: A specialized conveyor moves at a constant speed of $2.4\text{ m/s}$ in a straight line. Describe the type of motion.
questions.explanation: Constant speed in a straight line indicates uniform motion with zero acceleration.

questions.question: On a displacement-time graph, the line is straight and sloping upward. Describe the velocity of the object.
questions.explanation: A straight line with a constant positive slope on a displacement-time graph indicates uniform positive velocity.

questions.question: A velocity-time graph shows a horizontal line at $+19\text{ m/s}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line on a velocity-time graph means the velocity is constant (not changing). Therefore, the acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A heavy pendant hangs from a car's rearview mirror. When the car brakes suddenly, the pendant swings forward. Name the property of the pendant that is responsible for this.
questions.explanation: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion. The pendant tends to continue moving forward due to inertia when the car decelerates.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the net force required to accelerate a $0.75\text{ kg}$ model rocket at $40\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's Second Law: $F = ma = 0.75\text{ kg} \times 40\text{ m/s}^2 = 30\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A swimmer pushes off a wall with a force of $180\text{ N}$. According to Newton's Third Law, what is the magnitude of the force the wall exerts back on the swimmer?
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Therefore, the wall exerts a force of $180\text{ N}$ back on the swimmer.

questions.question: Calculate the weight of a $6.4\text{ kg}$ object on Earth, where the acceleration due to gravity $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Weight is given by $W = mg = 6.4\text{ kg} \times 9.8\text{ m/s}^2 = 62.72\text{ N}$.

questions.question: An object weighs $210\text{ N}$ on a planet where the acceleration due to gravity is $7\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the mass of the object?
questions.explanation: From $W = mg$, the mass is $m = \frac{W}{g} = \frac{210\text{ N}}{7\text{ m/s}^2} = 30\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $25\text{ kg}$ block is resting on a horizontal floor. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the floor is $0.32$. Calculate the force of friction acting on the block if it is sliding. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: The friction force is $f = \mu N = \mu mg = 0.32 \times 25 \times 10 = 80\text{ N}$.

questions.question: If the friction force acting on a sliding object is $55\text{ N}$ and the coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.25$, what is the mass of the object? ($g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Using $f = \mu mg$, we solve for mass: $m = \frac{f}{\mu g} = \frac{55}{0.25 \times 10} = 22\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $12\text{ kg}$ load is placed on top of a $38\text{ kg}$ platform. A horizontal force of $250\text{ N}$ is applied to the platform. Ignoring friction, find the acceleration of the platform and load together.
questions.explanation: The total mass being accelerated is $12\text{ kg} + 38\text{ kg} = 50\text{ kg}$. Using Newton's Second Law, $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{250\text{ N}}{50\text{ kg}} = 5\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Two carts, one with a mass of $26\text{ kg}$ and the other with a mass of $34\text{ kg}$, are connected by a rope and pulled by a $240\text{ N}$ force across a frictionless surface. What is the acceleration of the system?
questions.explanation: The total mass is $26 + 34 = 60\text{ kg}$. The acceleration is $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{240\text{ N}}{60\text{ kg}} = 4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A vacuum cleaner is pushed across a carpet at a constant speed by a force of $58\text{ N}$. What is the magnitude of the friction force acting on the cleaner?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means the net force is zero. Therefore, the applied force must exactly balance the friction force: $f_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} = 58\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $380\text{ N}$ force pulls a $40\text{ kg}$ object across a surface. The force of friction opposing the motion is $140\text{ N}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: The net force is $F_{\text{net}} = 380\text{ N} - 140\text{ N} = 240\text{ N}$. Acceleration is $a = \frac{F_{\text{net}}}{m} = \frac{240\text{ N}}{40\text{ kg}} = 6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $310\text{ N}$ horizontal force pushes a $50\text{ kg}$ block, causing it to accelerate at $5\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the magnitude of the frictional force acting on the block?
questions.explanation: The net force required to produce the acceleration is $F_{\text{net}} = ma = 50 \times 5 = 250\text{ N}$. Since the applied force is $310\text{ N}$, the friction force must be $F_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} - F_{\text{net}} = 310 - 250 = 60\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A jet ski moves through the water at a constant speed, overcoming $440\text{ N}$ of water resistance and $160\text{ N}$ of mechanical friction from its drive system. Find the total applied thrust needed to maintain this motion.
questions.explanation: Constant velocity implies zero net force. Therefore, the thrust must balance the total resistance: $F_{\text{thrust}} = 440\text{ N} + 160\text{ N} = 600\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A crane's engine provides a forward force of $4{,}200\text{ N}$. The cable friction is $900\text{ N}$. If the load moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the air drag?
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the net force is zero. Therefore, the thrust must equal the sum of the resistive forces: $4{,}200 = 900 + F_{\text{drag}}$, so $F_{\text{drag}} = 4{,}200 - 900 = 3{,}300\text{ N}$.

questions.question: The applied force on an object is $940\text{ N}$, and the air drag acting on it is $615\text{ N}$. If the object moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the mechanical friction?
questions.explanation: For constant velocity, the net force is zero, so the sum of resistive forces must equal the applied force. Therefore, $940 = 615 + f_{\text{friction}}$, so $f_{\text{friction}} = 940 - 615 = 325\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A forklift slowly lowers a pallet of bricks to the ground at a constant speed. Is the work done by the forklift on the pallet positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The forklift exerts an upward force on the pallet to control its descent, while the pallet's displacement is downward. Since the force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done by the forklift is negative.

questions.question: A tractor pulls a stump out of the ground, moving it in the direction of the pulling force. Is the work done by the tractor on the stump positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The tractor exerts a force on the stump in the direction of the stump's displacement. Force and displacement are in the same direction, so the work done by the tractor is positive.

questions.question: A $4.5\text{ kg}$ box is sitting on a rack that is $8\text{ m}$ above the floor. Calculate the box's gravitational potential energy relative to the floor. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: Gravitational potential energy is given by $GPE = mgh = 4.5\text{ kg} \times 10\text{ m/s}^2 \times 8\text{ m} = 360\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $0.6\text{ kg}$ projectile is launched and travels at a speed of $50\text{ m/s}$. What is its kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is calculated using $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}(0.6)(50)^2 = 0.3 \times 2{,}500 = 750\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A car has $4{,}000\text{ J}$ of kinetic energy before braking to a complete stop. How much energy was converted to heat by the brakes?
questions.explanation: By the work-energy theorem, the work done by the brakes equals the change in kinetic energy. All of the initial kinetic energy ($4{,}000\text{ J}$) is converted into heat.

questions.question: A jet plane gains altitude while maintaining a constant speed. Describe the changes in its kinetic energy (KE) and gravitational potential energy (PE).
options: Both PE and KE are constant
questions.explanation: As the plane gains altitude, its PE increases. Its speed is constant, so its KE is constant.

questions.question: An apple falls from a branch. Ignoring air resistance, describe the energy transition halfway down to the ground.
options: PE is being converted into KE
KE is being converted into PE
Both KE and PE are increasing
Both KE and PE are decreasing
questions.explanation: As the apple falls, its height decreases (so PE decreases) and its speed increases (so KE increases). Potential energy is being converted into kinetic energy.

questions.question: A bowling ball rolls at a constant speed along a level lane. Describe its gravitational potential energy (PE).
questions.explanation: Constant altitude on a level lane means the height is constant, so the gravitational potential energy is constant.

questions.question: An unstretched spring has a length of $16\text{ cm}$. When a mass is hung from it, the spring reaches a total length of $24.2\text{ cm}$. Calculate the extension of the spring.
questions.explanation: The extension is the increase in length: $\text{extension} = \text{final length} - \text{original length} = 24.2\text{ cm} - 16\text{ cm} = 8.2\text{ cm}$.

questions.question: A generator uses $8{,}000\text{ J}$ of energy to do $6{,}560\text{ J}$ of useful work. Calculate the efficiency of the generator.
questions.explanation: Efficiency is the ratio of useful work output to energy input, expressed as a percentage: $\left(\frac{6{,}560}{8{,}000}\right) \times 100\% = 82\%$.

questions.question: Calculate the total resistance of three resistors with resistances $14\,\Omega$, $36\,\Omega$, and $100\,\Omega$ when they are connected in series.
questions.explanation: For resistors in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances: $R_{\text{total}} = 14 + 36 + 100 = 150\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the total equivalent resistance of three identical $180\,\Omega$ resistors when they are connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For $n$ identical resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{eq}} = \frac{R}{n} = \frac{180\,\Omega}{3} = 60\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $15\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in series. This combination is then connected in parallel with a single $30\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The series pair has a resistance of $15 + 15 = 30\,\Omega$. This $30\,\Omega$ resistor is in parallel with the other $30\,\Omega$ resistor. The equivalent resistance is given by $\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{30} + \frac{1}{30} = \frac{2}{30} = \frac{1}{15} \rightarrow R = 15\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $60\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel. This combination is then connected in series with a $15\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel pair has an equivalent resistance of $\frac{60}{2} = 30\,\Omega$. Adding this in series with the $15\,\Omega$ resistor gives a total of $30 + 15 = 45\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the electrostatic force between two point charges of $6\,\mu\text{C}$ and $10\,\mu\text{C}$ separated by a distance of $0.06\text{ m}$ in a vacuum. (Use $k = 9 \times 10^9\text{ NÂ·m}^2/\text{C}^2$).
If the distance between two point charges is tripled ($3r$), while the charges themselves remain unchanged, how does the magnitude of the electrostatic force between them change?
options: It becomes $1/3$ of the original force ($F/3$)
It becomes $1/9$ of the original force ($F/9$)
It becomes $1/27$ of the original force ($F/27$)
questions.explanation: Coulomb's Law states that force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance: $F \propto \frac{1}{r^2}$. Tripling the distance ($r \rightarrow 3r$) reduces the force by a factor of $3^2 = 9$, so the new force is $F/9$.

questions.question: Three identical negative point charges are placed in a straight line with equal spacing between them. Charge A is on the left, B is in the middle, and C is on the right. What is the direction of the net electrostatic force on the rightmost charge (C)?
options: Toward the left (toward A and B)
Toward the right (away from A and B)
Zero (the forces from A and B cancel out)
questions.explanation: Charge B ($-q$) repels charge C ($-q$) to the right. Charge A ($-q$) also repels charge C ($-q$) to the right. Both forces on C are in the same direction (to the right), so the net force on C is to the right.

questions.question: A $45\,\Omega$ resistor is connected to a $135\text{ V}$ power source. Find the current flowing through it.
questions.explanation: Ohm's Law gives the current as $I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{135\text{ V}}{45\,\Omega} = 3\text{ A}$.

questions.question: An $8\,\Omega$ resistor has a current of $5\text{ A}$ flowing through it. What is the power dissipated by the resistor?
questions.explanation: Electrical power can be calculated using $P = I^2R = (5\text{ A})^2 \times 8\,\Omega = 25 \times 8 = 200\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A $20\,\Omega$ resistor is connected to a $100\text{ V}$ power supply. Find the power dissipated by the resistor.
questions.explanation: Using the formula $P = \frac{V^2}{R}$, we get $P = \frac{(100\text{ V})^2}{20\,\Omega} = \frac{10{,}000}{20} = 500\text{ W}$.

questions.question: If a charge of $2{,}700\text{ C}$ flows through a conductor in a time of $15$ minutes, what is the current?
questions.explanation: First convert time to seconds: $15$ minutes $= 900\text{ s}$. Electric current is $I = \frac{Q}{t} = \frac{2{,}700\text{ C}}{900\text{ s}} = 3\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A sensor's active area has a thickness of $0.000412\text{ m}$. Express this thickness in millimeters (mm).
